items.title: Taiwan evacuates residents trapped by flooding as tropical storm approaches
items.summary_auto: Taiwan evacuated more than 8,000 people from coastal and mountainous areas and closed schools ahead of the arrival of tropical storm Fung-wong. In Yilan County, rescue workers ferried people using boats and amphibious vehicles after torrential rains triggered severe flooding, and residents worked to clear debris and water from their homes.

items.title: Israeli president calls for end to settler violence against Palestinians after 'shocking and serious' attack
items.summary_auto: Israel's president on Wednesday called for an end to a growing wave of settler violence following a "shocking and serious" attack by Jewish settlers against Palestinians in the West Bank.

items.title: Nova Scotia sends its annual Christmas thank you to Boston
items.summary_auto: The Tree for Boston has been felled and the city's mayor, Michelle Wu, was in Lunenburg County for the occasion on Wednesday. As Brett Ruskin reports, the holiday tradition honours the help Boston provided Nova Scotia after the Halifax Explosion of 1917.

items.title: Brother of boy who died while they were in Ontario couple's care testifies at murder trial
items.summary_auto: The Milton, Ont., murder trial of a Burlington couple is hearing from the younger brother of a 12-year-old who died while the two were in the process of trying to adopt the boys. Becky Hamber and Brandy Cooney have pleaded not guilty in the 2022 death and to other charges.

items.title: Federal prison watchdog leaving post early over 'frustrations' with lack of prison reform
items.summary_auto: A watchdog that investigates the fair and humane treatment of federal prisoners is leaving his post two years early after becoming exasperated with what he says is the government’s unwillingness to address systemic human rights issues.

items.title: Ontario court rules province could allow online gamblers to play with people outside Canada
items.summary_auto: The Court of Appeal for Ontario has ruled that the province's regulated online gaming websites can legally allow gamblers in the province to play with people outside of Canada. It's a decision that could open the door to Ontarians playing peer-to-peer games, like online poker and daily fantasy sports, against players located outside of Canada.

items.title: After an incredible Tuesday night show, the northern lights could still be visible until Thursday
Northern Super League co-founder calls Final 'celebration of women's pro sport in Canada'
items.summary_auto: Northern Super League co-founder Diana Matheson is hopeful of a sold-out lower bowl at BMO Field for Saturday’s women’s soccer championship between host AFC Toronto and Vancouver Rise FC.

items.title: Daughter of Barry and Honey Sherman speaks on their deaths ahead of 8th anniversary
items.summary_auto: Eight years after Alex Krawczyk’s parents, Barry and Honey Sherman, were murdered, she is still holding out hope that justice will be served.

items.title: World oil and gas demand could grow until 2050, IEA says
items.summary_auto: Global oil and gas demand could grow until 2050, the International Energy Agency said on Wednesday, departing from previous expectations of a speedy transition to cleaner fuels following U.S. criticism about its climate focus.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Solar storms bring dazzling display of northern lights
items.summary_auto: Solar storms brought colourful auroras to unexpected southern places in Canada and the United States on Tuesday night — and there could be more to come.

items.title: Indigenous activists storm UN climate summit in Brazil, demanding action
items.summary_auto: Security has been tightened at the COP30 climate summit in Brazil after Indigenous activists and other protesters burst through barriers at the venue on Tuesday night. Indigenous groups from across Latin America sent representatives with demands for an end to logging, mining, farming and fossil fuel extraction in the Amazon.

items.title: Sidney Crosby joins program to support Canada’s soccer men ahead of World Cup
items.summary_auto: NHL player and 2010 Olympic hockey gold medallist Sidney Crosby, who knows more than a little about winning a major tournament on home soil, has signed on to help bang the drum for Canada in its 2026 World Cup campaign.

items.title: Man takes Hamilton city bus on a joy ride — making stops to let passengers on and off, say police
items.summary_auto: He made several stops along the way, allowing passengers to get on and off, police say.

items.title: Leonardo DiCaprio pays tribute to Jane Goodall at funeral
items.summary_auto: Goodall’s chimpanzee field research fundamentally altered how scientists understand the endangered primates, and how humankind understands its place in the world.

items.title: Jimmy Kimmel's bandleader and childhood friend, Cleto Escobedo III, dead at 59
items.summary_auto: Late-night talk-show host Jimmy Kimmel has announced the death of one of his oldest friends — his television program's bandleader, Cleto Escobedo III, after an episode of the TV program was abruptly cancelled. Saying that "we are heartbroken is an understatement," Kimmel's Instagram post says.

items.title: Anand announces new sanctions targeting Russian drones as G7 diplomats meet in Ontario
items.summary_auto: Foreign Affairs Minister Anita Anand is announcing more sanctions on Russia on Wednesday as she hosts a gathering in Ontario's Niagara Region of top diplomats from the G7 countries.

items.title: OPP say their largest-ever fentanyl bust was in Windsor
items.summary_auto: Authorities say 46 kilograms of the drug was recovered in late September after running search warrants in the southwestern Ontario border city.

items.title: French foreign minister, at G7 meeting in Canada, says U.S. boat strikes violate international law
items.summary_auto: During a G7 meeting in Ontario, France's foreign minister said the deadly boat strikes in the Caribbean carried out by the United States since early September violate international law. Colombia, California's governor and the Washington Post also weighed in on the strikes on Tuesday — but Canada has been relatively silent on the U.S. actions.

items.title: Ukrainian university students who fled war get a tuition break in Sask. That could soon change
items.summary_auto: Ukrainian students in Saskatchewan are urging the province to renew a tuition deal that lets them pay domestic student rates. The program is scheduled to expire in 2026, leaving many uncertain whether they can afford to stay in school.

items.title: Woman makes unlikely friends at B.C. snowmobile lodge during epic 5,700-km trek
items.summary_auto: An American woman who hiked a combined 5,700 kilometres through the U.S. and Canada over five months had an unlikely source of help right at the end of her trip — a group of B.C. snowmobilers holed up in their lodge.

items.title: 3 teens dead, another in hospital after crash near Hanover
items.summary_auto: Three young people are dead and a fourth is in hospital with life-threatening injuries after a single-vehicle crash near Hanover.

items.title: 20 Turkish troops killed in military plane crash in Georgia
items.summary_auto: Turkey's defence ministry said on Wednesday that 20 soldiers were killed in the crash of its military aircraft in Georgia a day earlier, as inspectors continued to seek clues what caused the NATO member's cargo plane to go down.

items.title: Federal investigation probes grocery store competition in Halifax
items.summary_auto: Since last year, an investigation into the ability of new grocers to set up in the Halifax Regional Municipality has been quietly ticking along under Competition Bureau Canada.

items.title: Peninsular Halifax doesn't have a French high school. Will that change?
items.summary_auto: Last week, the head of Nova Scotia's francophone school board said that rural geography is keeping some students from getting a French education. In the Halifax area, lengthy commutes due to traffic are keeping some students from getting a French high school education.

items.title: P.E.I. company seeks approval to import disease-resistant oyster stock from the U.S.
items.summary_auto: A P.E.I. company is seeking approval to import disease-resistant oyster seed and broodstock from the United States. Some Island oyster growers support the idea, but many in the wild oyster industry do not.

items.title: Swedish king’s visit highlights growing Canadian interest in Saab military aircraft
items.summary_auto: A few days before the federal budget was tabled, the CEO of Swedish industrial giant Saab flew to Ottawa to meet with the country's top bureaucrat, fuelling the sense a deal is brewing between the Canadian government and the military manufacturer. Now, the country's king, queen and a delegation of political and business leaders are set to visit from Nov. 18-20.

items.title: Front-line police patrol in Windsor sometimes at 'dangerously low' levels, says union
items.summary_auto: The Windsor Police Association (WPA) is pushing for mandatory minimums on the front lines after a recent patrol shift dropped to what they describe as concerning levels.

items.title: Renowned exoplanet researcher Sara Seager is bringing her quest to find another Earth back home to Canada
items.summary_auto: Canadian astronomical research is getting a big boost with the return of Sara Seager to Canada after around 20 years at MIT. Her research includes looking for life in the clouds of Venus and searching for Earth 2.0.

items.title: U.S. tourism faces $5.7B US loss as Canadians continue to stay home
items.summary_auto: Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. A U.S. Travel Association report forecasts a 3.2 per cent decline in international tourism spending in the country for 2025, a loss of $5.7 billion US compared to the previous year.

items.title: Comparing private and public surgery models in England, Scotland could inform Canada, experts say
items.summary_auto: As some Canadian provinces outsource certain surgeries to for-profit clinics, new research comparing the models in England and Scotland suggests shifting to private clinics can lead to longer wait times, reduced hospital capacity and increased inequality to access to care.
